awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Symmetry in Quantum Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
An important question facing fundamental physics is how the well-tested laws of Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics are consistent -- the question of quantum gravity. This question is central for understanding the very origin of our universe, the big bang.  Remarkable progress in understanding the big bang has occurred through the use of loop quantum cosmology (LQC), a simplified version of loop quantum gravity (LQG) for modeling the universe as a whole.  This award seeks to bridge the gap between LQC and full LQG.  Such a bridge would allow future comparisons of LQC with data to tell us exact details about the fundamental laws of quantum gravity. Bridging this gap requires answering a number of interesting fundamental conceptual questions.  A second part of this research aims to answer key questions regarding the Feynman sum-over-histories formulation of loop quantum gravity, in which space and time are treated in a more unified way, and to bring this formulation closer to completion. By enabling graduate students to participate in frontier physics, and to interact with other research groups, this award will have a broad and long-term impact on the development of future scientists. The results of the research will be disseminated to the scientific community through peer reviewed publication and scientific lectures, as well as to the general public through public lectures and other means.

With this award, the observational, cosmological consequences of different proposals for dynamics in LQG will be studied.  To accomplish this, the PI will first find an embedding of LQC states into diffeomorphism invariant LQG states that satisfy the diffeomorphism invariant, quantum criterion for homogeneity and isotropy recently established by the PI's group. This embedding, appropriately regularized, will enable different proposals for dynamics in LQG to be translated into LQC, and thereby to distinguish their observational consequences using established methods. The task of finding the corresponding LQC dynamics will be simplified by the fact that the resulting possibilities are severely restricted by diffeomorphism invariance, as proven recently by the PI's group. The PI also plans to further develop the sum over histories approach to LQG, known as spin-foams.  In prior work of the PI, the prevailing EPRL model of spin-foams was modified to correct its semiclassical limit, yielding what is called the proper spin-foam model. Since then, other research groups have indicated how this modified model may solve a number of long-standing issues in spin-foams.  These possibilities, as well as other issues in spin-foams, will be investigated with the present award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:


An important question facing fundamental physics is how the well-tested laws of Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics become consistent at the Planck scale -- the question of quantum gravity.  


This question is central to any attempt to understand the very origin of our universe, the big bang. Much remarkable progress in understanding the big bang has occurred through the use of loop quantum cosmology (LQC), a simplified version of loop quantum gravity (LQG) which models the whole universe, to a first approximation, as homogeneous and isotropic. This progress has led to new potential contact of quantum gravity with observation. 


The first outcome of the research of this grant is a definition of homogeneity and isotropy in LQG. More precisely, a definition was found which (1.) is “background independent”, that is, is invariant under arbitrary deformations of space (a condition required for it to make sense in any final theory of quantum gravity), (2.) respects the Heisenberg uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics, and (3.) respects the structure of continuum, non-truncated LQG. Achieving all three of these criteria was highly non-trivial and had never been done before. 


This definition of quantum symmetry allowed for clarifications of a number of issues in LQC. The resulting strengthened confidence in LQC can be regarded as a second principal outcome of the research. Indeed, this outcome was confirmed through independent means, again as part of the work of this grant, by directly applying the principle of background independence (invariance under spatial deformations) to show that various technical choices in the construction of LQC do not matter and all lead in the end to the same quantum cosmological model, namely that which has been principally used up until now in the LQC community.


The methods of LQC can also be applied to black holes: Inside of equilibrium, vacuum, non-rotating black holes, the natural direction of time evolution leads to spatial slices that are homogeneous, just as in the early universe. Application of the methods of LQC to the interior of black holes provides a quantitative understanding of the predictions of loop quantum gravity for black holes and their transitions to white holes (which are potentially observable in the case of primordial black holes). This idea of using LQC methods for black holes had already been used by previous authors to develop various loop quantum models of a black hole. The third principal outcome of the present research is (1.) a determination of which of these existing models are consistent with background independence (invariance under spatial deformations), (2.) determination of a family providing the most general such model compatible with background independence and all other required physical criteria, and (3.) a determination of which model in this family is `simplest´, in a certain natural and precise sense. This simplest model provides a loop quantum black hole model consistent with all required physical criteria, that is simpler than any proposed so far. 

In full loop quantum gravity, the prevailing model for the dynamics is defined using the `spin-foam´ framework, in which space and time are treated in a unified way. Exact calculations in this model involve a sum over arbitrarily refined discretizations of space-time. To calculate predictions from the theory, it is necessary to truncate this sum to some maximum level of refinement. Over a decade ago, arguments were given that the classical limit of such a truncated sum imposes that the discrete curvature (deficit angles) of the geometry belong to an unphysically restrictive discrete set, including, most notably, zero curvature (flatness). This is the so-called `accidental curvature constraint´ or `flatness problem' in spin-foams. Counter-arguments were also given in the literature against this result, and disagreement over whether it is true persisted for over a decade. 


The fourth principal outcome of this research is the resolution of this controversy by carefully correcting the counter-arguments to the flatness result and, thereby, in fact, turning them into new arguments for the flatness result. This analytical work, together with numerical work by another group explicitly verifying the flatness result, has led to a new broad consensus in the community that this result is in fact correct.


The fifth principal outcome of the present research is that this `flatness problem', although mathematically correct, is not a problem with the spin-foam theory itself, but rather a problem with taking the classical limit of a truncation of it. In particular, as part of the present grant, it was shown how analogous problems arise when taking the classical limit of truncations of even well-known and elementary quantum systems. 

Broader Impact:


Through partial financial support, this grant enabled four doctoral students and one post-doc to participate in the research described above, contributing in an essential way to the professional development of the next generation of scientists.
